results.title: They came to Wales
results.creator_credit: Barry Clayton, Edgar H. Anstey, James Ritchie and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: This kaleidoscopic film shows the new industrial Wales of nuclear power and electronics, of jet aircraft and optical glass developing in the older Wales of mountain, seascape and good company. We meet people who came to Wales from abroad and have found a new industrial and social life there.

results.title: They become Australian citizens
results.creator_credit: Ralph D. Hogg, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows how more thought has been given to the ceremony connected with naturalisation, and how the occasion has accordingly acquired a new significance in recent years.

results.title: These were the days: Victoria revisited
results.creator_credit: David Morgan and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description: Takes the audience around Victoria to see the preserving of history in country towns. The port of Echuca where the paddle streamer Canberra runs up the Murray River; Sovereign Hill in Ballarat; Burke Museum at Beechworth; The Museum of Agricultural Machinery at Warracknabeal; The Gippsland Folk Museum at Moe; Coal Creek mining town at Korumburra and the Pioneer Settlement.

results.title: These are scouts
results.brief_description: Shows what it means to be a scout in 1971 and gives details of how a local Scout Group is run. Included are many of the Movement’s activities such as camping, gliding, boating, caving, and overseas travel.

results.title: Thermometers: how they help us
results.brief_description:
Demonstrates the basic principle that liquids expand when heated and contract when cooled. Shows how a thermometer is built and used and depicts different types of thermometers.
Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Thermal wonderland
results.creator_credit: Stanhope Andrews and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Aerial view of Rotorua and the volcanic formation of the surrounding country. Geysers, mud pools, terraces, hot springs, and the color of the rock formation in the thermal district. Glimpses of Whakarewarewa, Rotomahana, Wairakei, and the Waikato River with the Huka Falls.

results.title: There go the boats
results.creator_credit: R.K. Neilson Baxter, John Shearman and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: The film sketches the development and usage of inland waterways in Britain. Before the coming of railways natural waterways were the chief means of transport, while in the middle of the eighteenth century the cutting of artificial waterways developed rapidly. The advent of railways brought about the decay and abandonment of many canals, and today only a limited number are used for transport; others supply water for power stations and for main canals, or are used as reservoirs by farmers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: R.K. Neilson Baxter, John Shearman and British Transport Films

results.title: There are yachts at the bottom of my garden [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Many people believe that eighteen footers are the most exciting boats racing on Sydney Harbour. They certainly attract more spectators than any other class of boat. This film talks about sailing on Sydney Harbour. By contrast with those who live in one of the world’s capitals, such as London, and who may have to drive some distance to reach their boats, the average Sydney sailor is lucky: there are literally yachts at the bottom of the garden. In Italian.
